final_answer: The clinic should obtain written informed consent from the patient before performing any procedures. If the patient refuses treatment, the clinic should not perform the procedure. If the patient consents but does not pay for the procedure, the clinic can still proceed as long as there is no undue influence on the decision-making process (e.g., coercion). However, if the patient pays only part of the cost upfront and then fails to make additional payments after surgery, this may constitute fraud by the patient because they agreed to pay full price but did not follow through. In such cases, the clinic may need to take legal action against the patient to recover its losses. On the other hand, if the patient has already undergone surgery and cannot afford further treatment due to financial hardship, the clinic could consider offering alternative treatments at reduced prices or providing free services instead of pursuing collection efforts.
